overview: This is a report on an investigation into allegations of fraudulent conduct by locally recruited UNON staff. The investigation was prompted by reports of fraudulent activities at the Nairobi-based UNICEF/Somalia Support Centre, where staff were using falsified appointment letters to secure loans. The investigation presents findings and recommendations to UNON management.

methodology.description: ID/OIOS conducted interviews with relevant staff at UNICEF premises in the presence of two Senior UNICEF Managers. They were unable to interview all involved, some due to passing or refusal, and conducted document reviews of UN-SACCO loan files, selecting based on criteria such as high loan amounts and long contract durations.
interviews: Interviews with UNICEF management and staff in presence of two senior management members
Interviews with UN-SACCO and UNON staff
documents_reviewed: UNICEF internal documents related to appointment letters and official seal usage

background.context: Allegations surfaced of staff using fraudulent appointment letters to obtain loans.

investigation_details.subject: Fraudulent conduct by locally recruited UNON staff

allegations.description: UNON staff submitting fraudulent letters of appointments to obtain loans.
allegations.findings: In the interviews with ID/OIOS, UNICEF staff admitted to misusing official letterhead and seal to secure loans. However, due to the limited access to records, conclusive evidence identifying UNON staff involvement was not determined.

allegations.description: Senior UNEP Manager involved in staff letter writing to UN-SACCO that may imply contract extension.
allegations.findings: Interview confirmed writing of letters at the request of staff for loan obtaining reasons, warning that it could imply contract renewals.

allegations.description: UNICEF staff produced fraudulent letters of appointment after denial of official appointment letters.
allegations.findings: The fraudulent letters were accepted by UN-SACCO management despite clear differences from legitimate documents.

findings: There is no evidence of similar improper conduct by UNON staff in obtaining loans from UN-SACCO.

actions: UNON to implement stronger controls over access to official seals and stationery
Conduct regular audits of records linked to UN-SACCO loans
UNON Management to inform UN-SACCO Management to require original official documentation from UNON staff
UNON to ascertain awareness among personnel officers about instances of denied requests for appointment letters
Secure appointment and renewal processes to prevent misuse of potentially misleading letters
Request UN-SACCO Management to systematically confirm employment duration information with UNON Personnel offices (ID Rec. IV05/050/04)
